53. In Divisions like Bandar, a large-scale assignment was made during the 1960-1970s under crash assignment programmes.
Answer by Assignment Department: These lands which were largely fallow with lack of fresh water irrigation facilities were converted into aquaculture and got alienated from the original assignees. Since the aquaculture was not brought in to the definition of Agriculture” until recently, the resumption and re-assignment of above lands was not done all this period. The assignment registers of these lands, which were prepared about 60 years back are either lost or not available. The existing entries in adangal are also not reliable. In the absence of details of original assignees, the Tahsildars are not able to update pattadars names in DLR.
2 After amendment Act, 2007, the right of the assignee to seek restoration of land after resumption even if he continues to be landless poor is not absolute. (MRO Vetapalem and another, 2007 (3) ALT 489)
  
   It is true, in Kolleru lake a large scale assignment was made about 50 years back, but in some villages assignment records were not traced, now there is no option available, except to conduct present enjoyment, survey and assigning to present enjoyers, subject to eligibility and duly following assignment rules, otherwise there is a likelihood of filing of WPs. Without conducting enjoyment survey and making fresh assignment, LPM shall not be generated, because large number of ineligible land lords are in cultivation.
54. If in assigned lands, the original assignee transfers the land to another person who is enjoying the land for many years. Will this land comes under patta land or government land as notices are to be served separately during ground truthing? Answer by Assignment Department: As per section 5(1) (2) of the A.P Assigned lands (Prohibition & Transfers) Rules 1977, the transfer of assign lands to another person will be treated violation of conditions and shall be resumed the land and re-assigned to the original assignee or new assignee - or any violations observed with reference to the revenue records and enjoyment, that land shall be treated as AWD. An ex- serviceman who was assigned Govt. Land is not prohibited to sell the assigned land after ten years of grant. (S. Bade vs. Dist. Collector, Visakhapatanm, 2005 (5) ALT 635). But subsequently it was instructed such lands shall not be sold without obtaining NOC from the District Collector (G.O.Ms.No. 307 Rev., dt. 6.6.13).
INAM LANDS
55. ‘A’isenjoyinglandclassifiedas‘InamDry’anditwas‘ServiceInam’dulypurchased from ‘B’. In whose name should LPM be generated.
The provisions under Act 16 of 2013 amended to Inam Abolition Act, 1956 prohibits such transactions to any person in any manner is null and void. Hence, generation of LPM is not feasible.
Note: The Andhra Pradesh (Andhra Area) Inams (Abolition and Conversion into Ryotwari) (Amendment) Act, 2012 or the Act 16 of 2013 that is deemed to have come into force on 26th November, 1956 provides that where any person other than the concerned charitable or religious institution or endowment obtained a patta for such service inam lands, this will be deemed as null and void. The Act 16 of 2013 holds that only the person to whom the inam land was given to render service shall be entitled to continue in the enjoyment of such land provided he continues to render the service for which the land was given.

The provisions under Act 16 of 2013 amended to Inam Abolition Act, 1956 prohibits such transactions to any person in any manner is null and void. Hence, generation of LPM is not feasible.
Note: The Andhra Pradesh (Andhra Area) Inams (Abolition and Conversion into Ryotwari) (Amendment) Act, 2012 or the Act 16 of 2013 that is deemed to have come into force on 26th November, 1956 provides that where any person other than the concerned charitable or religious institution or endowment obtained a patta for such service inam lands, this will be deemed as null and void. The Act 16 of 2013 holds that only the person to whom the inam land was given to render service shall be entitled to continue in the enjoyment of such land provided he continues to render the service for which the land was given. In this case, since A has purchased a service inam land that is impermissible and considered as null and void, LPM should not be generated in his name
56. An extent of Acs.1.30 cents is under the enjoyment of ‘P’ but RSR is not updated as per the Dotted Land Regulation Act, 2017. Should the LPM be generated in the name of P as shown as Govt. Land?
The LPM should not be generated in the name of ‘P’ till receipt of the decision of the District Level Committee( DLC) as per the provisions under AP Dotted lands Act. Till de-notification of such property by the Government, the land remains as G.D. and the pattadar column shall be dots only.
57. UAW lands are assigned. However, there is no record of conversion to modify the nature & classification. What should be done?
If the conversion record is not available, & assignment is found genuine, the records of survey sub-division, AWD conversion, the entries made in ROR-1B have to be
    
   ratified co-relating with the entries of made in 4(1)(c). When the primary records are not available, the UAW land remains UAW and a fresh proposal for converting from UAW to AWD has to be submitted before District Collector/RDO and subsequently, the assignment can be made as per G.O.Ms.250, Revenue (Assgn.I) Department, dated 15.05.2018.
58. For Service inams, no remarks are recorded in the 13th & 14th columns while they are shown as GD in Adangal ?
The Inams should be declared by Form-II and subsequent Gazette publication u/s. 3(6) of Inam Abolition Act, 1956. Further, the amended Act 16 of 2013 prohibits that the service Inams in any manner (service to whole village/Any Institution/charitable institution/Endowment/Land holder) is null and void.
59. Certainminorinamlands,particularlypersonalinamsarenotconvertedintoryotwari land as the concerned landowners failed to prove their rights or their predecessor- in-title rights over the subject land as on the crucial dates prescribed in the act i.e., 07.01.1948 & 26.11.1956. Unless these crucial dates are changed to a recent dates, settlement of these lands are not possible. In DLR, these lands have been continuing with “Inam” nature and the farmers in these lands who are belongs small and marginal of sections society, would not get any benefits of re-survey.
Before conversion of Inam to Ryotwari, the pre-abolition record with name, T.D.No., Cist receipts will be examined to notify the bonafied owner in the Inam Fair Register. If no name was recorded in pre-abolition record and survey operations conducted on later date as per usage and nature of these lands will be considered as Government lands. Further, Survey operations conducted after lapse of decade’s i.e, 1980s and the lands are being cultivation by the ryots, the Director of Survey & Settlement will recommend the Government to fix up cut-off date for considering the claims of the ryots for grant of pattas.
60. Inams given to Chakalis, Mangalis etc., are subsequently sold away and the new pattadars appear from the 10(1) accounts prepared in the 1980s. We are treating them as settled ryotwari lands. Is this correct?
The provision of Act 16 of 2013 provides no rights and the ryotwari patta granted earlier are also null & void. A decision can be taken after appropriate amendments/clarifications given to the Act of 16 of 2013.

Further, Survey operations conducted after lapse of decade’s i.e, 1980s and the lands are being cultivation by the ryots, the Director of Survey & Settlement will recommend the Government to fix up cut-off date for considering the claims of the ryots for grant of pattas.
60. Inams given to Chakalis, Mangalis etc., are subsequently sold away and the new pattadars appear from the 10(1) accounts prepared in the 1980s. We are treating them as settled ryotwari lands. Is this correct?
The provision of Act 16 of 2013 provides no rights and the ryotwari patta granted earlier are also null & void. A decision can be taken after appropriate amendments/clarifications given to the Act of 16 of 2013.
LPM Related
61. A had 1 acre of land in Sy No 100/1. Ac 0.20 cents have been taken by government for building a road (without formal acquisition) several years ago and sub-division has not been affected. How much of land is to be shown in his LPM?
The LPM should reflect the actual enjoyment on the ground by A i.e. Ac 0.80 cents. It is to be verified from the requisition department if the acquisition proceedings were carried out or alternate procedures of land assembly like voluntary land donation. Further, the 8A register of the Tahsildar office/FMB may be traced to find out whether the sub division had been ordered and carried out. For the 20 cents, for which acquisition proceedings may have to be initiated, the nature of land/classification will be government/road.
62. A owned 8.5 acres of land. 1.5 acres of land was acquired for the railways in 2001 though mutation was not affected. He continues to cultivate on the land and shows proof of his enjoyment and also produces land revenue receipts. He claims non-
    
   receipt of compensation and insists on recording entire extent of land in his LPM. What should be done in this case?
The LPM should reflect the actual extent in enjoyment by A at the time of resurvey, excluding the land acquired for the railways. The land acquisition awards should be verified if the compensation was paid to the landowner or deposited in civil deposits. The village records should be verified to see if the possession of land was formally handed over to the requisitioning department and if not, necessary steps may be taken in this regard.
63. Landowner C has 3.45 acres of land extent of land recorded in the Adangal and his pattadar passbook. The field measurement is 3.20 acres. How much of land extent should be included in the LPM?
The LPMs should mirror the actual position on the ground subject to consent of the landowners or be included in the disputed category. In case the enjoyment does not match with the records, the Tehsildar may verify records held by C (sale deed, Partition deed, Succession, will deed etc.) to rule out wrong entry if any in the Adangal and Pattadar Passbook. Further, the entire survey number has to be surveyed and if all the interested persons agree to the extent per the records/enjoyment, the Mobile Magistrate may record respective extents and the LPMs will accordingly reflect the extent. However, if the affected landowners do not agree and chose to go for appeal, the same may be reflected in the Land Register as disputed category.
64. Bisenjoying4.5acresoflandwhilehisrecordsshow4acres.Hisneighbourshavean extent of 3.2 and 2.3 acres in the records and their area after actual measurement is 3 acres and 2 acres respectively? How much land extent should be recorded against each in the LPM?
Notices have to be issued to B and his neighbours and if all agree to the extents as per actual enjoyment, the LPMs may reflect the extents enjoyed. In case, they do not agree, the LPMs will reflect the decision of the Prescribed Officer (Mobile Magistrate) as per the AP Surveys and Boundaries Act, 1923. Incase the landowners go for appeal, the Land Register may reflect the same.
65. A’snameappearsintheAdangalandvillagerecordsbothfortheancestralproperty as well as his self-acquired property. He and his son have mutually divided the properties and enjoying on the ground. Should a partition be registered? Should there be separate LPMs generated as per their share. What are the procedures to be followed?

How much land extent should be recorded against each in the LPM?
Notices have to be issued to B and his neighbours and if all agree to the extents as per actual enjoyment, the LPMs may reflect the extents enjoyed. In case, they do not agree, the LPMs will reflect the decision of the Prescribed Officer (Mobile Magistrate) as per the AP Surveys and Boundaries Act, 1923. Incase the landowners go for appeal, the Land Register may reflect the same.
65. A’snameappearsintheAdangalandvillagerecordsbothfortheancestralproperty as well as his self-acquired property. He and his son have mutually divided the properties and enjoying on the ground. Should a partition be registered? Should there be separate LPMs generated as per their share. What are the procedures to be followed? Till the time the procedure is complete, should they be given one LPM There is no need for a partition deed to be registered when both the son and father accept for the division of the property and agree with the extents. There shall be separate LPM for son and father as per their respective shares in the partition deed. Further, as for affecting necessary changes in the RoR which will follow the resurvey process, the partition deed should be properly stamped as per Art. 40, of Schedule 1-A of the Indian Stamp Act and the recording authority should record statements from all concerned and keep a complete record of enquiry (ref,CSS & Lr’s Ref. No. ROR/A/444/89 dated 31st May, 1989).
66. Mhas2.20acresinSyNo35/1andBhas3.10acresinSyNo.26/2ButAhasbeen enjoying Bs land and vice versa for over 25 years. How do we fix the land extents in the LPMs, as per enjoyment or ownership?
Notices should be issued to M and B regarding their recorded and enjoyed extents. The LPMS can reflect their share as per enjoyment if ‘M’ and ‘B’ agree for the same
 
   and to be entered in the disputes register if they disagree. Necessary steps and due process for registration of the lands and entry in the revenue records should follow.
67. A, B, and C are the sons of D who passed away couple of years ago. They stay in a joint family and do not wish the land to be partitioned? What should be the procedure and how should LPM be generated?
When D, the pattadar is dead, the logical step should be to record his legal heirs as pattadars as per their share as land cannot be continued in the name of dead person. They have to either partition the land as per their enjoyment or share or agree to record name one of the sons (generally the elder son as the Karta of the Hindu joint family). In case they want to continue in one person’s name, one LPM may be generated and if they decide to partition, different LPMs will have to be generated.
68. X, Y and Z are enjoying ancestral property without registration. Can their actual extent be reflected in the LPMs?
LPMs can reflect their land extents as per their enjoyment/share in the ancestral property after local enquiry/consent of all legal heirs and a partition deed. Due process for record correction should follow during the resurvey process.
69. Xhasregisteredhislandcoupleofyearsbackbutthesurveynumberandsubdivision is wrongly registered. At the time of LPM generation, what is to be done?
LPM can be generated as per enjoyment with the correct survey and sub-division number provided, he gets his sale deed rectified by the registration department.
70. M,NandOarebrothersandhavepurchased6acresoflandtogether15yearsback through a registered sale deed. Mutation has not been done. They claim to have equal shares but are enjoying slightly unequal shares on the ground. Should LPM generated for equal shares or should it be as per actual enjoyment?
If enjoyment is different from records, the Mobile Magistrate may take a decision based on the mutual consent of landowners/verification of records/ valid partition deed. LPM may be generated accordingly.
71. Though the lands have been sold and purchased several times (registered), the name of the actual landowner is appearing in the Adangal and RoR. Can the names of new owners be shown in the LPMs based on registration deed while mutation process goes on?

LPM can be generated as per enjoyment with the correct survey and sub-division number provided, he gets his sale deed rectified by the registration department.
70. M,NandOarebrothersandhavepurchased6acresoflandtogether15yearsback through a registered sale deed. Mutation has not been done. They claim to have equal shares but are enjoying slightly unequal shares on the ground. Should LPM generated for equal shares or should it be as per actual enjoyment?
If enjoyment is different from records, the Mobile Magistrate may take a decision based on the mutual consent of landowners/verification of records/ valid partition deed. LPM may be generated accordingly.
71. Though the lands have been sold and purchased several times (registered), the name of the actual landowner is appearing in the Adangal and RoR. Can the names of new owners be shown in the LPMs based on registration deed while mutation process goes on?
All such cases pending for mutation should be taken up early on in the process by VRO and concerned landowners may be advised to complete the mutation process so that their name can be included in the pattadar column against the given LPM in the land register.
72. XhasnotpaidconversionchargesforNALAbutisutilisingthelandfornon-agriculture purpose. Should LPM be created for agriculture or non- agricultural land? According to Section 6 of the Andhra Pradesh Agricultural Land (Conversion for Non- Agricultural Purposes) Act, 2006, if any agricultural land has been put to non- agricultural purpose without payment of the required Conversation Tax, land shall be deemed to have been converted into non-agricultural purpose imposing a fine of 50 percent over and above the conversion fee. Also, any fee or penalty which remains unpaid after the specified date shall be recoverable as per the provisions of the Andhra Pradesh Revenue Recovery Act, 1864. LPM may be created for non-
 
   agricultural land while payment of applicable charges including penalty by ‘X’ may be taken up by the concerned authorities.
73. IfthereisanyexistingstructuresinPattaland,whichisneartoVillageSitePoramboke, then should LPM be generated for agriculture or non-agriculture land?
The cluster of houses at any place in the village is to be demarcated as extended Gramakantam as per the amended AP Rights in Land and Pattadar Passbooks Act, 2021. The structures in the extended gramakantam are to be treated as non- agricultural land subject to payment of necessary tax for conversion of agricultural land. So, LPM can be generated as non-agricultural while payment of applicable charges including penalty may be taken up by the concerned revenue authorities.
74. A and B are brothers. Both are enjoying the ancestral land on field in equal shares but while A’s name is entered in webland, B’s is not and he does not have any documentary evidences. Now both are asking for generation of LPMs. What is to be done in this case?
LPM can be generated as per the decision of the MM i.e. If A does not object to the equal share of B and enters into a partition deed. However, if A objects, A’s name may be entered in the Land Register and place in the dispute category.
75. ‘X’ is a non-tribal enjoying tribal land in the Agency area. Can he be recorded as a LPM holder?
The Andhra Pradesh Scheduled Areas Land Transfer Regulation 1/59 as amended by 1/70, explicitly prohibits any person in a Scheduled Area from transferring lands to anyone other than a Scheduled Tribe. Such transactions are considered as null and void u/s 3(1) of the Regulation and the transferee non-tribal is not entitled to the property. Hence there is no question of recording of a non-tribal holder’s name in the LPM.
76. Landisinthenameofthediety.However,Yisinpossession,enjoymentandhasvalid registration deeds and pattadar passbook. Should LPM be generated in the name of Y or incorporated as an Endowment land?
The correct legal position is that the idol is the juristic person recognized by law and in this juristic person the dedicated property vests. An obligation has been cast upon the State under the provisions of the Endowments Act to protect endowment/temple lands. Lands in the name of the deity should necessarily be recorded as Endowment land and necessary proceedings initiated against Y under the Andhra Pradesh Land Encroachment Act, 1905.

Such transactions are considered as null and void u/s 3(1) of the Regulation and the transferee non-tribal is not entitled to the property. Hence there is no question of recording of a non-tribal holder’s name in the LPM.
76. Landisinthenameofthediety.However,Yisinpossession,enjoymentandhasvalid registration deeds and pattadar passbook. Should LPM be generated in the name of Y or incorporated as an Endowment land?
The correct legal position is that the idol is the juristic person recognized by law and in this juristic person the dedicated property vests. An obligation has been cast upon the State under the provisions of the Endowments Act to protect endowment/temple lands. Lands in the name of the deity should necessarily be recorded as Endowment land and necessary proceedings initiated against Y under the Andhra Pradesh Land Encroachment Act, 1905. However, it may be useful to also verify who has registered the land and whose name the land in question is recorded as per RSR, Diglot or SFA prior to initiating action under the 1905 Act.
77. Land is recorded in the name of deceased B. Should LPM be generated in the name of B and C who are his legal heirs of the ancestral property and presently enjoying the land?. Should the land extent be according to their share or as per enjoyment? Land extent can be recorded as per their enjoyment in LPM if agreed by both B and C, based on the partition deed. Alternately, if they want the boundaries to be changed based on their share, this can be decided by the Mobile Magistrate after due enquiry and LPM generated accordingly. If either of the same is not acceptable to both of them, land may continue to be shown in the name of B and included in the dispute category to be decided as per Rule 9 (1) (c) (ii) and decide their shares.
 
   78. A has transferred 5 acres of land to his daughter at the time of marriage and she is cultivating the land. Can her name be incorporated in the LPM prior to validation u/s 5A of the RoR Act?
Rule 22, Andhra Pradesh Rights in Land and Pattadar Pass Books Rules, 1989 (for regularization of transfer other than by registered document) requires persons to be recorded as occupants in Adangal/Pahani Patrika or in the Record of Rights. Subject to this requirement, the validation process can be taken up under u/s 5A of the AP Rights in Land and Pattadar Passbooks Act, 1971. The name of the daughter can be provisionally included and finalized in the Land Register after the validation u/s 5A.
79. Though the lands have been sold and purchased several times (registered), the name of the actual landowner, X is appearing in the Adangal and RoR. Can the name of new owner, Y be shown in the LPMs based on registration deed while mutation process goes on?
In all such cases, the mutation process shall be initiated early on. Under the AP Rights in Land and Pattadar Passbook Act, 1971, the entries in the [title deed and pass book] may be corrected either suo motu or on an application made to the Mandal Revenue Officer. The name of the pattadar may be entered in the Land Register after the completion of the mutation process.

CIRCULAR
 
No. REV05/77/2022-CCLA & SPL CS, Dated:04/12/2022
 
               Sub - Resurvey -YSR Jagananna   Shaswata Bhu Hakku
                        mariyu Bhu Raksha - Field Level POLR  - Certain
               guidelines issued – Regarding.
*****
1.Background 
       The Government of Andhra Pradesh, with an aim to provide modern,
digital land and revenue records has taken up the task of completing
Resurvey in all 17,460 villages in the state by December, 2023.   
 
              During fled level workshops at Srikakulam, Ananthapuramu and
Ongole, Collectors brought forward the fact that there is a need to purify
Revenue records even before the receipt of the Ortho rectifed Image of
the Village. They suggested that such an exercise, ahead of the drone
fying in the villages, ensures timely completion of the survey process and
results in records which mirror ground reality.
 
               Such a mechanism would provide  extra time for resolution  of
these issues of mismatch between the record and the feld situation.The
survey  team/  Mobile  magistrate  can   utilise  this  period  to  locate  non
resident farmers, serve them   with the  statutory notices, examine the
documents presented before them,   and prepare the records to be put to
ground truthing more efciently.     
 
               Landholders/  farmers will also beneft by   availing of this extra
opportunity for fling representations and to be present for the diferent
statutory procedures/ enquiry that need to be followed in updation of their
records. 
               Collector Prakasam has taken up this exercise in a big way and
the district has benefted tremendously from the same.
 
It is noteworthy, that all the   district have completed the village level
purifcation of land records (desk exercisea as per extant instructions inFile No.REV05/77/2022-DIR-CSSL

this regard. The fnal output of this exercise is being used together with
the ORI to conduct the ground truthing / boundary confrmation by land
owners. 
 
Thus, it would sufce that the output of this desk based POLR is
supplemented by fled level POLR, which is to be taken up with updated
adangal, FMB/ Village Map and/or any reference image of the village, like a
Google earth image( This is not essential to begin the exercise a.
 
2. Field level purifcation of Land Records
 
Therefore, it is   decided to take up   Field Verifcation of POLR 
output in all 17460 (minus the 4000 Villages where ORI is already 
received), using  available survey records like village Map/ FMB, the   RoR 
records and/or latest adangal and Satellite Images from Free source Online
Platforms (This is not essential to begin the exercise a. 
 
               This program shall be conducted through the specially constituted
village feld verifcation teams in all of the 13,460 villages( where the ORIs 
are yet to be receiveda, with in a period of 100 days positively.   
 
               The preparation of Satellite-based image for Physical verifcation 
of PoLR Data will be done by the concerned Village Surveyor and the 
Image tile sheets will be handed over to the Field Verifcation Team for 
further procedure .
 
3. What is Field level POLR     
In Resurvey, all the feld level activities such as Ground Truthing &
Ground Validation take the PoLR Output as the starting point. 
Before commencement of Drone Flying, Revenue Records of each
village need to be made up to date by completing work on: Mutations,
Modifcations, Addition/Deletion of R.S. No’s, F-Lines, Patta Sub Division,
Joint Cultivation, 22A & Dotted Lands, Updation of deceased cases etc.File No.REV05/77/2022-DIR-CSSL

All these issues can be resolved by fling necessary applications
either  through  Village  Secretariats  or  through  Meeseva  duly  following
prescribed procedure.  This is the proposed Field Level Purifcation of Land
Records (FPOLRa.  
If the issues identifed during FPOLR   are resolved prior to Drone Fly,
the execution of GT & GV work will become easy and further preparation
of DLR could be completed in a time bound manner. 
Hence to conduct feld to feld enquiry and update the PoLR Data by
verifying the feld position, a Field Verifcation Team shall be constituted.
 
4.     Preparatory steps for FPOLR  
Satellite-based image.
  Preparation of Satellite-based image will be done by the concerned
Village  Surveyor  and  verifed  and  approved  by  the  mandal  surveyor.  
Image tile sheets will be handed over to the Field Verifcation Team for
further usage. 
Survey and revenue records
The Tahsildar shall ensure that the   following records/registers, which
are available are provided to the feld verifcation team.
i.POLR-6A report  
ii.Latest  Adangal 
iii.Village Map 
iv.Field Measurement Book  
v.Satellite based map 
vi.22-A List 
vii.Land Audit report  
viii.Notional Khatas / Zero Accounts/others  
ix.Details of Government Khatas.  
x.ROR I-B Register  
 
5.Constitution of FPOLR TeamFile No.REV05/77/2022-DIR-CSSL

The Field Verifcation Team will be comprising of the following secretariat 
staf: 1a Village Revenue ofcer 2a Village Agricultural Assistant 3a Village 
Digital Assistant 4a Village Engineering Assistant 5a village surveyor and 
any others as decided by the Collector.
 
6. Procedure
STEP 1: The team should   lay down a detailed village wise/
survey number wise visit schedule in advance and give it
wide publicity.
STEP 2: The FPOLR team shall inspect each and every survey number in
POLR 6-A data in presence of concerned farmers and demarcate their land
boundaries on the feld and draw the boundary lines on Satellite-based
Maps. 
STEP3: Each entry in POLR 6-A record should be cross checked survey 
number wise on the ground. If there is any mismatch found between the 
details in POLR 6-A and on-ground status, it should be written in the 
remarks col. of POLR 6A.
               
               a) Survey/survey related issues 
i.If there is any joint cultivation on ground, action may be taken for 
Sub-Division of Land. 
ii.If any Patta Sub-Division was not taken place, action to be taken for   
Patta Sub-Division.  
 
b) Revenue / RoR related issues  
          (ia Family disputes should be resolved (Consent of all members is
               essentiala and mutation initiated.
         (iia If there is one person is on ground and the name of  another was
         entered in Webland, the FPOLR Team shall collect the evidence fromFile No.REV05/77/2022-DIR-CSSL

the both sides and take action for mutation be initiated. 
         (iiia If the particular land was listed in 22A or categorized as Dotted
         lands, the team should check the relevant documents available with
        them and immediately direct them to apply for deletion from 22A
         lists/ regularization under Dotted land Act, 2017 by fling application
          for respective services in VSWS. 
       (iva In case of any land acquisition, if the survey number is still          
shown as private land in Web land, then the classifcation of the           
land taken under LA, should be changed in all records.
       (va  In case, any alienation of Assignment lands is noticed,                
            immediate action shall be taken as per POT Act. 
         (via  If the Pattadar column is noted as “Others” in Webland           
         Adangal, but the cultivators exist on ground in all such cases,          
         mutation  shall be initiated. 
      (viia  In case of court disputes pending over a land parcel (Civil Court/
       High Court/ RDO Court/JC Courta, the details should be collected and
      handed over to the Tahsildar for entry in remarks column.
    (viiia Ensure that names of deceased persons are recorded in the           
Revenue Records. If dead Pattadars found during feld survey, the     legal
heirs of the deceased Pattadars may be requested to fle                       
an application for Mutation .
      (ixa All types of encroachments of Government lands should be 
demarcated and joint action shall be taken by concerned Mandal Surveyor 
and Revenue Inspector.
 
7. RECORDING ISSUES IN REMARKS COLUMN : All resolved and 
unresolved matters should be entered in the remarks column of POLR 
records/Adangal for fnal incorporation/resolution during Resurvey 
process.
 
8.  Satellite  Images  not  available  cases:  In  villages,  where  Field
Verifcation is not possible through Satellite based image( orchards, dense
vegetation.  etca,  it  shall  be  completed  utilizing  FMB,  Latest  Adangal,File No.REV05/77/2022-DIR-CSSL

Village Map and other best available records.

10.Monitoring and Supervision
The output proforma shall be monitored daily and necessary action shall
be taken swiftly by the concerned Tahsildar and Mandal Surveyor upon the
issues raised during feld verifcation.
 11.  Hence, all District Collectors  are hereby instructed   to initiate  and
complete this process of Field Verifcation of PoLR   in all of the 13,460
villages( where the ORI s are yet to be receiveda, with in a period of 100
days positively.
They shall task the Joint Collectors and Additional District Magistrate, to
personally  oversee  the  successful  conduct  of  this  program  and
achievement of its objectives. This item would be reviewed in the weekly
Thursday teleconference and in various other review meetings.
12. Collectors are requested to conduct training for all the Viallage survey
teams as well as Tahsildars  by Video Conference  within a week from

13.  CSSLR  is  requested  to  ensure  that  this  training  of  feld  staf is

based on “District, Mandal, Village, Division and Aadhaar Number ”

details based on Katha Number.

“No Records Found ” and will allow to go further process.

on Aadhaar Number or Katha Number .

“Sale, Partition Deed outside the Family, Partition Deed within Family,  
Exchange”  
 
 
 
❖ Donor Land Details shall be fetched when the Mutation Category  is “Gift 
     Deed”  
 
 
 
❖ Testator Land  Details shall be fetched when the Mutation Category  is 
“Registered Will”  
 
 
 
❖ Releasor Land Details shall be fetched when the Mutation Category  is 
“Release ”

fetch and verify t he Land d etails of the person who

(Claimant /Donee/ testate/ Releasee, etc ).

displayed to fetch the  Registration Details of the Land from Registration 
Department .

“Digital Assista nt shall need to check the Registration Document and enter the 
details accordingly”  
 
Step-9: 
Once “ Get Registration Details ” button is clicked the Sy.Nos recorded for that 
respective document at the time of Registration shall be fetched and displayed in 
dropdown based on above mentioned inputs.  
 
Note:  
Here  IF  
Mutation Category =  Sale deed  
AND  
Aadhaar Authentication of Applicant (Pattadar Authentication (Owner)) = Aadhaar of the 
claimant  at Registration Details  
Then {Registration Details will be fetched an d will proceed further for Submitting the 
application}  
ELSE IF  
Aadhaar Authentication of Applicant (Pattadar Authentication (Owner)) NOT EQUAL  
Aadhaar of the claimant at Registration Details  
Then  
Representative Authentication will be done to confirm the R epresentative who 
appeared at the time of Registration.

For other deeds: Gift/Release/Will/Exchange (Aadh aar of claimant is not mandatory at 
the time registration)  
IF  
Aadhaar Authentication of Applicant (Pattadar Authentication (Owner)) = Aadhaar of the  
claimant at Registration Details  
Then {Registration Details will be fetched and will proceed further for Submitting the 
application}  
ELSE IF  
Aadhaar Authentication of Applicant (Pattadar Authentication (Owner)) NOT EQUAL  
Aadhaar of the claimant at Registr ation Details

Hakku mariyu Bhu Raksha Pathakam)  is categorized into 5 major phases  comprising 26 
sub-phases  as given below: - 
 
  PHASE WISE ACTIVITIES – RESURVEY (REVENUE & IT PROCESS) 
Phase No.  Sub-Phases Phase Description

1 Circular I

5 Circular V 
6 Circular VI

3 Ground Truthing Data Entry 
4 Disposal of Mutations & Rectifications 
5 Generation of Form 31 & 32 
III Ground Validation 
1 Disposal of Revenue Appeals 
2 Generation of Form-38

5 Updation of OTC Register 
6 Launch of Database for regular services & operations

 SUBPHASE 1: PURIFICATION OF LAND RECORDS – CIRCULAR I  
  The initial activity of POLR is based on Circular I provided by the Revenue 
Department which is to complete the data entry of the Manuscript RSR (Digitization of 
Manuscript RSR) in the format as prescribed in Proforma-1 in the Webland2 portal for all the 
Revenue Villages in the State.  
Pre-Requisites :  
The base essential records needed to start the Purification of Land Records process of any 
Village are: 
1. RSR/Diglot/A register 
2. Fair Adangal / FLR 
3. FMB 
4. Others, if any 
Flow Hierarchy: 
VRO (Entry/ Edit)  VS (Remarks)  RI / DT / MS (Remarks)  Tahsildar (Edit /Approve) 
 RDO /Sub Collector (Verify/ Approve). 
Task – I: Data entry  
The First Task is to complete the data entry of the Manuscript RSR in the already prescribed 
Proforma-1  in the Webland 2 portal for all the Revenue Villages in the State.  The Joint 
Collectors shall ensure that the data entry is completed in the stipulated time frame. It may 
be noted that Manuscript RSR cannot be changed at this stage and all data be correctly 
entered strictly as per entries in Manuscript RSR. Any attempt to enter incorrect data, not 
found in Manuscript RSR shall be viewed very seriously. Tahsildars/ RDOs / Sub-Collectors 
shall compare the data in Manuscript RSR and the data entered in Proforma-1  to ensure the 
correctness of data entry. Once the data entry is completed for the manuscript RSR, the 
computer program downloads the Webland RSR automatically and points out the variations 
between the Manuscript RSR and the Webland RSR.

Task – II: Rectification of variations  
  In Task 2, the goal is that the data entered from the Manuscript RSR and the Webland 
RSR are thoroughly verified and variations between them eliminated as per the computer 
entries. This will ensure that the Webland RSR and the Manuscript RSR are one and the same. 
For this, the system is already developed in the Webland portal in Proforma-1 and in case 
any change has to be brought about in the Webland RSR (as there is a difference with 
Manuscript RSR), the change has to be carried out as per the prescribed procedure in the SOP. 
The operating procedure (SOP) is already prescribed vide this office circular instruction dt. 
29.06.2020 and the updated version is attached in Annexure I.  
  Every change suggested shall be written in the remarks column. The change shall be 
initiated by the VRO, then scrutinized by the Village Surveyor, and go through the prescribed 
procedure till it is finally approved by the Sub Collector / Revenue Divisional Officer (upon 
eOffice file approval by respective Joint Collector as the Joint Collector is the competent 
authority (District Settlement Officer)) . However, all efforts shall be made by the 
Tahsildars/ RDOs to ensure that the Webland RSR matches the Manuscript RSR at the stage 
of the Tahsildars/ RDOs itself.  
  It was suggested that collective and teamwork at the Village and Mandal level would 
help in speeding up the process. Accordingly, the following process is indicated:  
a) At the Village level, the VRO and VS along with the Special Officer (RI/MS/DT) will 
work as a team and verify the variations if any between the Webland RSR and the 
Manuscript RSR.  
b) The VRO, Tahsildar, and the Sub Collector / RDO have the edit option and approve 
or recommend to the approval authority. Others Officers like VS, RI/MS/DT will 
enter their remarks and recommendation and forward to the next level. The entire 
process is a collaborative one and all officers are jointly and severally responsible for 
bringing out a purified Webland RSR record. Variation

 c) If the Webland RSR and the Manuscript RSR entries are the same, the computer 
program shows that record in “Green” colour. If the Webland RSR and the manuscript 
RSR entries are in variation, it may require:  
I. addition of Survey / Sub-Division No (shown in Blue colour),[entry missing in 
Webland RSR] or  
II. deletion of Survey / Sub-Division No (shown in Red colour) [ excess entry in 
Webland RSR] or  
III. Rectification in total extent, Land Nature, Land Classification, Pattadar Name 
& Remarks Columns, etc (shown in Yellow colour)  
d) For the records which are shown in Green, Blue, Red, or Yellow colour, the VRO, VS, 
and Special Officer identify the reason and propose a correction in the Webland RSR 
and record their remarks in the relevant column and send to Tahsildar. 
e) The Special Officer, namely RI/DT/MS shall verify all the entries Survey No wise 
(100%) to ensure that the data in the Webland RSR is compared with the Manuscript 
RSR, record his remarks and forward to Tahsildar. 
f) The records which are in Green will be approved at the Tahsildar level. The Tahsildar 
will fully verify these records and the data and approve the record. Upon approval, 
the record will turn Dark Green. 
g) The records which require the addition of Survey / Sub-Division No (shown in Blue 
colour) will be sent to the RDO/ Sub Collector by Tahsildar with his recommendation. 
Upon approval by RDO / Sub Collector, the such record will turn into Dark Green. 
h) The records which require the deletion of Survey / Sub-Division No (shown in Red 
colour) will be sent to the RDO/ Sub collector by Tahsildar with his recommendation. 
Upon approval by RDO / Sub Collector, the such record will turn into Dark Green. 
i) The records which are shown in Yellow colour will be sent by the Tahsildar to the 
RDO/Sub-Collector with his remarks and recommendation. The Sub Collector / RDO 
will examine the same and approve. Upon approval by the Sub Collector / RDO, the 
such record turns into Dark Green. 
j) The approving authority i.e. Tahsildar for the green record, RDO /Sub Collector for 
Blue and Red records with the assistance of their office staff should cross-check all the

 entries Survey No wise with the physical copy/scanned copy of the Manuscript RSR, 
for which they are the approving authority, to ensure the correctness of data. 
k) The Tahsildar has to crosscheck all the records forwarded by the RI/DT/Mandal 
Surveyor. Further, RDO/Sub Collectors shall ensure the correctness of the record 
which are forwarded by the Tahsildar and check at least 10-20% of the records in green 
colour, which are already approved at the level of the Tahsildars. 
l) If the variation can’t be sorted out because of a valid reason, it is desirable that the 
matter is deeply enquired into, if necessary by field enquiry, and all attempts to be 
made to resolve it. Even after this if the variation can’t be resolved, then an entry has 
to be made in the Issues Column explaining the in detail so that it is settled at the time 
of Re-Survey. The same approval authority will approve the issue, as per the colour 
code. Once the issue is recorded and approved, the record will turn into an “Orange” 
colour.

Task III: Base Records   
 
The base essential records needed to start the Purification of Land Records process of any 
Village are: 
 Original Manuscript RSR of the Village. 
 Village Map - Manuscript copy and Digitized Village Map. 
 All Manuscript/FMB’s of the Village and Digitized FMB’s. 
 ROR Register (Forms 1A & 1B) of the Village. 
 Pattadar Master Database of the Village. 
 Webland Adangal of the Village. 
 22(A) Database –available in Tahsildar Office/ with Registration Department 
 Sarkarbhoomi Database 
 Other similar records deal with the record of rights, surveys, etc of the Village.

 SUBPHASE 2: PURIFICATION OF LAND RECORDS – CIRCULAR II 
 
Objective: - The mapping of Survey. No / Sub-divisions and their extents of confirmed 
Webland RSR, with the Survey no./ Sub-divisions of Webland adangal by comparing their 
extent and recording the reasons for various if any  
 
Flow Hierarchy: 
VRO (Entry/ Edit)  VS (Verify / Remarks)  RI / DT / MS (Verify / Remarks)  Tahsildar 
(Edit /Approve)  RDO /Sub Collector (Verify/ Remark / Approval)  Tahsildar (Final 
Approval) 
 
STEP 1: Mapping and establishing a clear relationship between the Survey No / Sub-
division Nos available in the Webland RSR with that of Survey No / Sub-
division Nos of Webland Adangal. 
 
  To perform this task, the comparison statement of Webland RSR with Webland 
Adangal is automatically generated in a prefilled manner duly grouped by Webland RSR 
Survey Number wise and will be downloaded in the respective VRO login (Annexure-I) .

  The computer program has been designed in a manner to help in the exercise by 
grouping the Survey/ Sub-division numbers of RSR and Webland Adangal.  The total 
extent of each Survey / Sub-division number in Webland RSR and the corresponding total 
extent of Survey / Sub-division numbers in Webland Adangal should match.  If the totals 
are matched, the record will be shown in GREEN colour, and not matched record will be 
shown in RED colour.

Page 25 of 144 
   As we know, splitting of survey numbers, formation of new survey numbers and 
clubbing of survey numbers will take place due to land acquisition, alienation, assignment, 
Mutations, etc., In order to ensure a clear relationship between the Survey / Sub-division 
numbers available in the Webland RSR with that of Survey / Sub-division numbers of 
Webland Adangal, the mapping of newly formed Survey / Sub-division numbers (due to 
above reasons) in Adangal with the base survey number of the RSR by selecting survey/ 
Sub-division numbers from the existing Webland Adangal and tagging it to the respective 
original base survey number is required to be done.  The computer program allows for 
picking up Survey / Sub-divisions in Webland Adangal and placing it against the correct 
Survey / Sub-division number of RSR. Once the mapping is done, the Survey / Sub-
division number will be appended to the corresponding Webland RSR Survey / Sub-
division, and the Subtotal extent would automatically change accordingly. 
  In this process, it should be noted that no new Survey / Sub-division number can be 
added/deleted/modified for matching the Sub totals of Webland RSR, with Webland 
Adangal.  Mapping will be done only by picking up the survey numbers already existing 
in the Webland Adangal and adding it to the corresponding Webland RSR survey number.  
The process shall be completed for all Survey numbers ( including Green Coloured 
records) of the village before proceeding to step 2. 
STEP 2: Recording reasons for the variations in Survey/Sub-division numbers and extents between Webland RSR and Webland Adangal if any. 
 
  After completion of Step 1, the computer will regenerate the comparison statement 
and the records of each village will again be coded with two colours: 
 Tallied cases  (Green Colour) 
 Not Tallied cases  (Red Colour) 
  The main task of this step is to verify every not tallied case and record reasons for the 
variations in the provision available in the software. 
During this process the possible variations are: 
 Survey / Sub-divisions extent in Webland Adangal is over and above the 
corresponding survey/sub-division in Webland RSR. 
 Survey / Sub-divisions extent in Webland Adangal is less than the 
corresponding survey/sub-division in Webland RSR.

Page 26 of 144 
  The Survey / Sub-divisions are existing in Webland RSR but are not present in 
Webland Adangal. 
 The Survey / Sub-divisions are existing in Webland Adangal but are not 
present in Webland RSR. 
  While the computer program assists in this exercise, significant work has to be done 
based on existing records and field information and local enquiry of the concerned field 
Officials.  In some cases, this may even need field visits.  The field staff shall identify the 
Survey / Sub-divisions wise extent differences between Webland RSR and Webland Adangal 
and shall examine the reasons for such variations and record the same against the survey 
number and also upload the enquiry/justification report and all other relevant supporting 
documents in the software. 
   The probable reasons for variations and procedure for recording reasons are explained 
in Annexure II . 
  The SOP to be followed for completing Step-1 & Step-2 is explained in Annexure-III. 
STEP 3 : 
  After completion of Step 1 & Step 2 all the records of a village will be in Green (Tallied 
cases) or in Red (Not Tallied cases) colour  
 The VRO shall verify survey number-wise all records and update the remarks for 
variations of Survey Numbers, and Extents.  
 The VS shall make 100% cross verification of the records, certify and submit the entire 
village record along with his remarks if any. 
 The RI / DT / MS shall make 100% cross verification of the records and submit the 
entire village records along with their remarks to Tahsildar for fixing up the 
Variations. 
 PLEASE NOTE THAT VRO, VS, AND RI/DT/MS will work as a team and each is 
responsible to ensure the correctness of the data. 
 After certifying the data by VRO, VS, RI/DT/MS, the Tahsildar shall verify all records.  
Based on the justification and enquiry reports and other documents,  enters his 
remarks (for approval/rejection) pertaining to the variations of Survey numbers and 
extents.  All the documents which are edited by the Tahsildar will be shown in BLUE 
colour.

   It may also be noted that editing RSR is not an option, as it implies changing 
manuscript RSR.  Hence, if this is to be done, the Tahsildar / Sub Collector / RDO may

STEP 4 : After completion of Step 1, Step 2, Step 3 and Output Proformas IIA. 
 
  The Tahsildar shall download / Print the village record including the RED colour 
records and initiate one e-office file for each village.  A detailed examination should be done 
for each variation (Red coloured records).  All efforts should be made to identify the causes 
and required rectification.  The details will be submitted by the Tahsildars to Sub Collectors 
/ RDOs who will examine the issues fully and then the eOffice file should be circulated to 
Joint Collectors duly noting the variation, reasons for variations and the rectification 
required. 
  On approval of the required rectifications by the Joint Collectors, the prescribed 
procedures for carrying out the rectifications shall be followed by the Tahsildar / Sub 
Collectors / RDOs and finally proceedings issued in the connected eOffice file, by the Joint 
Collector listing the rectifications required in Proforma B of POLR.  Thereafter, the Joint 
Collector can request PD CMRO for re-opening of Proforma B, in which corrections can be 
done under supervision and approved at the level of Sub Collector / RDO.  This facility will 
be made available only once, so that progress of subsequent work does not suffer.  This will 
complete the exercise and the remaining red entries can be resolved only by survey at the 
time of Resurvey. 
  The eOffice record of the village with the Joint Collectors proceedings will also be a 
basic record of the village, to be used at the time of the Re-Survey.  More time can be taken in 
respect of these villages with red coloured entries if required, and these villages should not 
be in the first 1/3rd of the villages selected for Re-Survey. 
  The above exercise will achieve the following objectives: 
1) Set up a relationship/link between each survey/sub-division number in 
Webland RSR with the survey/sub-division number in Webland Adangal. 
2) Equate the area of each survey/sub-division number in Webland RSR with 
the total area of all linked survey/sub-division numbers in the Webland

 SUBPHASE 3: PURIFICATION OF LAND RECORDS – CIRCULAR III 
 
Objective: - The standardisation of Land Nature, Land Classification against the Webland 
records. 
Flow Hierarchy: 
VRO (Entry/ Edit)  VS (Verify / Remarks)  RI / DT / MS (Verify / Remarks)  Tahsildar 
(Edit /Approve)  RDO /Sub Collector (Verify/ Remark / Approval)  Tahsildar (Final 
Approval) 
  The Land Nature and Classification are the most important in the Adangal. Land 
Nature can be changed from one category to other with proper permissions. Updation of all 
such cases/transactions in the relevant columns of Webland Adangal from time to time is 
necessary. 
  In order to purify the Land Nature and Land Classification, the step by step 
procedure to be followed is described as under: 
  On successful completion of Proforma –II activities, Proforma –III will be generated 
automatically for that Village. In that Proforma, Sy. No, Sub- Division Number, Total Extent, 
Land Nature & Land Classification as per Webland RSR and Webland Adangal will be 
shown in a prefilled manner. These details need to be verified by VRO & VS and RI/DT/MS 
together in Webland RSR & Webland Adangal in accordance with the ground position, in 
V.R.O Login. 
  As a part of the process, VRO shall select the exact Land Nature and Land 
Classification from the drop down box provided in Proforma –III. (Annexure – I) and enter 
the details of Land Nature and Land Classification and he/she shall enter the 
recommendations. They can also upload supporting document for fixing up the Land 
Nature and Land Classification. 
  VS shall make 100% cross verification of the records, certify and submit the entire 
Village records along with his remarks, if any. 
  RI/DT/MS shall verify 100 % Land nature & land classification of all records and can 
enter Remarks (Optional) and forward entire village to Tahsildar. 
  Tahsildar should verify 100 % Land nature & land classification of all records and can 
edit 12- 15 columns if necessary, duly uploading supporting document and detailed 
justification in Remarks column. And Tahsildar edited records (Col. 12-15) will be shown in 
BLUE colour after SAVED. Tahsildar forwards the entire village to RDO/Sub Collector for 
scrutiny. 
  RDO should verify 100 % Land nature & land classification of all records and can send 
back the records of entire village with Remarks to Tahsildar if required for carrying out 
necessary changes, if any, as noted in the Remarks. Otherwise, RDO approves the records. 
  Upon approval of entire village by RDO through digital signature, the village data will 
be frozen and the village record is sent to Tahsildar for final approval. Tahsildar will 
approve the entire village record at once with DS and after digital signing once for village

 data by Tahsildar, a village wise output proforma IIIA report is generated in RDO and 
Tahsildar logins. 
The ultimate aim of the third stage is that Standardization of Webland Adangal Land 
Nature and Land Classification by fixing up of Broad and sub categories respectively.

 SUBPHASE 4: PURIFICATION OF LAND RECORDS – CIRCULAR IV 
 
Objective: - The objective of this Circular of PoLR is to create a Village wise Master Data 
of Pattadars, linked to their Khata numbers and Aadhaar Numbers.  The mobile number 
and Aadhaar linked photo will also be verified in this stage of PoLR. 
Flow Hierarchy: 
VRO (Entry/ Edit)  RI / DT / MS (Verify / Remarks)  Tahsildar (Verify / Remarks) 
 RDO /Sub Collector (Verify/ Approval) 
  In situations where Aadhar number can’t be seeded there we can opt for the other 
relevant documents of Pattadar like Passport number/PAN number/CIN 
number/Registration number. 
  The input proforma IV will appear in VRO’s login in prefilled manner in respect 
of Columns 1-10. Where Aadhaar number is already entered (in Column number -6) 
Column numbers 13-15 will be greyed as these columns need not be entered in these 
cases. 
  The VRO and RI/DT of the village will work as a team to purify the Proforma – 
IV. The VRO and RI/DT will together verify each and every detail in the columns above 
for identifying discrepancies if any. 
Step-1: 
  To compare the Pattadar name (Column No.3 read with Column 4 viz. Circular 
IV) with the Aadhaar linked Pattadar name (Column No. 7 read with Column No. 8 viz. 
Circular IV) by VRO & RI/DT together 
1. If the Pattadar name does not match, the Aadhaar no (Column 6) is to be verified 
first. 
Case 1: Aadhaar No.is Wrong and Name/Person is Correct 
The correct Aadhaar number need to be entered in Column 6 viz. Circular IV by the VRO, 
duly uploading the Photocopy of the Aadhaar card for which edit Aadhaar number 
option has been provided. The record will be highlighted in YELLOW COLOUR and 
repopulated with new Aadhaar number details, viz., Col no 7, 8, 9, and 10 viz. Circular 
IV will be repopulated with the data relating to the Correct Aadhaar number. 
Case 2: Aadhaar number is correct but the names do not exactly tally 
The VRO & RI/DT team together needs to verify and ensure that the name of the person 
reflected in the Aadhaar card is the same person as the Pattadar in Column No. 3 viz. 
Circular IV read with Column No.4 viz. Circular IV.

acquired through Sale, Partition, Gift, Court Decree, Sadabainama and Succession etc.,..

 SUBPHASE 6: PURIFICATION OF LAND RECORDS – CIRCULAR VI 
 
  This activity will be taken up after completion of Circular – I to IV for the entire 
Village. 
  The objective of this Circular is to conduct quality check of the POLR data by an 
Officer of the rank of Deputy Collector so that the data can be used during Resurvey for 
Ground truthing. 
Flow Hierarchy: 
Tahsildar (Edit /Remarks)  RDO /Sub Collector (Verify/ Remark)  Joint Collector 
(Verify & Final Approval) 
 
Circular VI consists of the following option 
1. POLR Data for Print Out 
2. Output Proforma 6A 
3. POLR Data for Process 
4. Download WebLand-1 Data As on Date. 
 
STEP 1: Quality check by Dy Collector rank official. 
The Collectors/Joint Collectors shall identify and issue proceedings designating Quality 
Check Officer, (QCO) at the earliest. 
The Purified Record is a prerequisite of Resurvey and hence the QCO shall ensure the 
POLR data is qualitatively checked. 
STEP 2: Data for Quality Check 
POLR Data for Print Out: This report is used for Quality check which will contain all 
proformas data i.e. I to V comprehensive report for entire village.  
The Tahsildar to take printout of comprehensive report & separate output reports of all 
proformas i.e. I – V which in-turn forwards to the QCO (Quality Check Officer) 
STEP 3: Output of Circular VI. 
Output Proforma VIA: This Output Proforma VIA report is a prerequisite for Ground 
Truthing input data entry which will be generated automatically for the village in 
Tahsildar login after completion of Circular C. 
Output Proforma 6-A report consists of 31 Columns and the columns 5, 6, 16, 17, 21, 23, 
24, 30, 31 columns viz. Output Proforma 6-A have to be filled by the village survey team 
(VST) by visiting field.

 STEP 5: Procedure for carrying out corrections in the POLR DATABASE  
POLR Data for Process: This option is used to carry out the changes suggested by QCO 
after generating the proceedings with list of changes that need to carry out.   
The Work flow in this process is as below: 
  Tahsildar Sub Collector/RDO  Joint Collector. 
Based on the proceedings of the QCO, Tahsildar will perform the necessary actions and 
forward it to RDO. All such records on being escalated by Tahsildar turn into BLUE 
Colour.  The SC/RDO will verify the changes/modifications done by the Tahsildar and 
provides the recommendations and send to the JC. Among all BLUE colour records, RDO 
recommended records shall turn DARK GREEN  colour and not recommended records 
shall turn LIGHT GREEN  colour The JC will verify the changes /modifications done by 
the Tahsildar and recommendations provided by RDO and finally Approve / Rejects the 
changes/modifications. All records approved by Joint Collector will turn to 
BLACK&WHITE  and all rejected records turn into Grey colour.  
If Approved by JC then those Changes/Modified data will be updated. 
If Rejected by JC then the data will not be changed. 
Once this activity is completed successfully then the Output Report 6-A will be updated 
dynamically, which will in-turn forwarded to VST for further action. 
 
STEP 4: Download WebLand-1 Data as on Date: 
This report contains the records which were Changed / Modified / Ratified / Mutated 
in Webland 1 from proforma 2 ported date to as on date.  This is 15 Column Adangal data 
which will be handed over to VST team. 
The ultimate aim of this stage is to carry out Quality check by QCO.

 PHASE II – GROUND TRUTHING  
POLR : Completion of POLR is the pre-requisite for the Ground Truthing "Output Form 
VIA" which is the reference record that must be carried by Village Survey Team for 
Ground Truthing exercise gets generated only after completion of Quality Check activity 
prescribed in proforma VI of POLR. 
Quality Check  : After receipt of ORI, the quality check of the ORIs shall be completed. 
The Village Boundaries, Gramakantam Boundaries and Government land boundaries 
whether clearly visible or not in the map must be checked mandatorily.  
Formation of Village Survey Teams : Sub Collector/ RDO shall 
form dedicated Village Survey Team (VST) comprising of the local VRO & Village 
Surveyor acting under supervision of dedicated RI/DT. If necessary, near by villages 
VROs and Village Surveyors also shall be formed into additional teams for assisting the 
local Village Survey Ground Truthing Team. 
Equipment required for Ground Truthing :  The Village Survey Teams must be equipped 
with the necessary instruments viz GNSS Rovers, ETS. Chain & Cross staff etc. All the 
records mentioned in the Resurvey SOP shall be carried to handle land related issues 
easily in the field. 
Activities to be undertaken in ground truthing : 
i. Instructions with regard to boundary not clear / fudge :  
 Any missing points/fudge in the image shall be collected on the ground using the 
GNSS Rovers.  
ii. Instructions with regard to formation of new sub-division: 
 The list of all pending applications pertaining to F-Line. disputes / Patta Sub-
division of the respective village shall be completed following due procedure as 
per S&B Act. 1923 
 As per the willingness of the land holders, wherever there is any new request of 
sub dividing the land parcels or amalgamation of the land parcels, such petitions 
also shall be collected and redressed as per the provisions laid in S&B Act. 1923. It 
is desirable that the sub-divisions requested shall also be made physically on the

Page 55 of 144 
 ground to get a perfect picture of the Land Parcels Citizens maybe encouraged to 
take up such activity 
iii. Process regarding amalgamation / joint cultivation : 
 Whenever, there is a joint cultivation of different holdings and if the farmers are 
not willing to form bunds for the purpose of joint cultivation, the procedure given 
in P.No. 33 of Resurvey SOP - Duly mark dotted line where ridges do not exist on 
ORI hard copy of the boundaries demarcated on request. Collect the data for the 
new points with Rover and enter the data in Form 18. 
iv. Instructions with regard to government lands :  
 During Ground Truthing all Government lands shall be identified & verified 
including lands covered under Section 22(a)(i)(a to e) of the Registration Act, 1908 
and other Acts, Rules in force.  
 The boundaries of the Government lands shall be fixed as per original boundaries 
only. While recording the boundaries of Government lands, no separate LP 
Numbers or Chalta Numbers shall be given even if it is under cultivation / 
unauthorized occupation / encroachment / grabbing by any individuals.  
 Utmost care must be taken care while dealing fixation of boundaries to 
Government Lands. No Government land or part of the Government land shall be 
shown added to any other neighbouring Patta or Assigned lands. Any deviations 
to these instructions shall be dealt seriously.  
SUB PHASE 1 : COLLECTION OF GROUND TRUTHING DATA 
 The Output VI-A report generated after completion of Circular VI shall only be used 
for Ground Truthing Activity. 
 The Village Survey Teams / Mandal Teams shall ensure 100% accuracy of Land 
Records data, which will be used for generation of Notices i) Notional Sub-division 
No, ii) Chaltha No iii) LPM No and iv) LPM No Extent for Ground Truthing and 
other phases of Resurvey. 
 Utmost care shall be taken to process the identified mutations / rectification 
following due procedure prior to initiation of Ground Truthing.  If any mutations /

Page 56 of 144 
 rectifications were noticed in the transit period between PoLR & Ground Truthing, 
the same shall also be processed following due procedures. ( Disposal of Mutations, 
Rectifications, shall be taken according to relevant Sections / Rules of Acts, Rules 
in force). 
SUB PHASE 2 : DATA ENTRY OF CORRELATION STATEMENT : 
 After completion of field Ground Truthing, the textual and spatial data have to be 
processed. 
 The Spatial data has to be started with allotment of Land Parcel Numbers, Land 
Parcel Extents, following due procedure as per the instructions issued by 
Commissioner, SSLR. 
 Utmost care shall be taken while allotting the Land Parcel numbers.  Same Land 
Parcel Number shall not be assigned to one Land Parcel having two different 
Land Natures / Land Classifications. (In such case the parcel has to be divided 
into two land parcels). 
 Same Land Parcel Number shall not be assigned to two Pattadars except in the 
case of HUF issues.   
 The Land Parcel number will be manually prepared by Village Surveyor and shall 
be Quality check by Mandal Surveyor and shall certify the accuracy of allotment of 
Land Parcel Numbers, Land Parcel Extents. 
 The online Correlation Statement entry module has been provided to Village 
Surveyors login. 
 The Village Surveyors, shall use “Add” option, for providing the LP Number, LP 
Extent etc details for an existing record in case of one to many mutation cases only.  
(the notional sub-division number shall be given following notation process as 
prescribed in Annexure – Procedure and illustrations for Notional Sub-division), 
Sub-rule (1) Rule 19 of the A.P.Rights in Land and Pattadar Passbooks Rules, 
1989).  When there is no change of sub-division , the Notional Sub-division 
column shall be kept blank.

Page 57 of 144 
  The Village Surveyors shall complete the data entry of Notional Sub-division 
number, Chalta Number, Land Parcel Number, Land Parcel Extent, duly uploading 
the certified copy of Mandal Surveyor. 
 The POLR data duly integrated with Land Parcel Numbers will be pushed to 
respective Village Revenue Officer Login for processing the Ground Truthing Data 
Entry. 
 The Village Surveyors while choosing the option of “Add” for creation of new row.  
This option shall be used only when an sub-division is required

SUBPHASE 4:  DISPOSAL OF MUTATIONS & RECTIFICATIONS  
 The mutation, rectification requests identified and generated by Village Survey 
team will be forwarded to Deputy Tahsildar / Tahsildar for further generation 
of statutory forms and disposal of the same following due process as per Act, 
Rules in force. 
 The Deputy Tahsildar / Tahsildar shall initiate generation of statutory forms 
without lapse of time, as the statutory period has to be followed and after 
disposal of the mutation, rectifications only the accurate can be pushed to 
Form-31, 32, which will be used for generation of notices for Ground 
Validation.  
 Scrutiny of mutations, rectifications shall be conducted while disposing the 
requests. 
 
SUBPHASE 5: GENERATION OF FORM 31 & 32: 
 Form 31s (LP Number wise Correlation), Form 32 (Survey Number wise 
Correlation) will be generated after completion of Ground Truthing. 
 The Data of Form 31 & 32 will be shared to SSLR Department through API for 
generation of notices for Ground Validation Activity. 
 Form 31 and 32 further will be used as input for the Draft Land Register.

SUBPHASE 1 – DISPOSAL OF REVENUE APPEALS  
   The Government vide GO RT No 530 Law (LAQ&J-Home-Courts-B), 
dated:07.06.2021 has appointed the Deputy Tahsildars, Mandal Revenue Office, who 
are appointed to the resurvey programme and that they are to be called as DEPUTY 
TAHSILDARS (RE-SURVEY) AS SPECIAL EXECUTIVE MAGISTRATES w.e.f 
21.12.2020 till the completion of Re-Survey Programme in their respective mandals.  
  The Deputy Tahsildars were conferred with certain powers under sections 107 
to 24, 129 to144, 174 (4) and 176 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 (Central Act 2 of 
1974) in their respective jurisdictions as allotted by the Government. 
 The job chart of Dy. Tahsildars (Re-Survey), known as MOBILE MAGISTRATES 
consists of powers delegated under (1) the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 (Central Act 
2 of 1974) (2) AP Survey & Boundaries Act 1923 and (3) AP Rights in land and pattadar 
Passbooks Act 1971. 
Under the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 (Central Act 2 of 1974), certain powers have 
been delegated for quick disposal of Revenue Appeals.

Verification: 
 The Mobile Mandal Magistrate should duly take necessary steps in receiving 
the appeals and have to verify each appeal, conduct proper enquiry and field 
inspection then the Mobile Mandal Magistrate have to issue the speaking 
orders related to that appeal.  
 
Disposal of the Appeals: 
 All the received appeals have to be disposed within 30 days from the date of 
filing the appeals.  The appeals approved by the Mobile Mandal Magistrate 
should be recorded in to DLR.  Entire records pertaining to Appeals shall be 
maintained safely and shall be securely placed under the custody of the 
Deputy Tahsildars (Mobile Magistrates).

Page 64 of 144 
 Disposal of Mutations / Rectifications: 
 During the process of Ground Validation, there might be a chance of certain 
Mutations / Rectifications identified in patta lands by Village Survey team and the 
same have to be redressed by the Village Survey team following due procedures. 
 In case of Mutations / Rectifications, the disposal of the same shall be followed 
with due procedures. 
 Utmost care shall be taken while confirming the title and there shall be no 
deviation against legal aspects and that every action performed during the 
mutation / rectification process shall be legally tenable and according to the 
existing Acts, Rules only. 
 Utmost care shall be taken that the Land Registers reflect the Rightful person 
against respective land. 
Submission of Ground Validation records to Post Ground Validation Stage:  
After completion of Ground Validation, the entire record shall be processed in Post 
Ground Validation Stage for generation of Draft Land Registers / Resurvey Land 
Register and Other Resurvey Records mentioned in SOP for Resurvey. 
 
SUBPHASE 2 : GENERATION OF DRAFT LAND REGISTER (FORM 38)  
 Draft Land Register, Resurvey Land Register are the final land records after the 
completion of Resurvey activity, which includes both the land details and Pattadar 
details. Once the quality check of online module for Draft Land Register is 
completed by Joint Collector, then it will be notified under Resurvey Notification 
Under Section 13 of A.P. Survey & Boundaries Act, 1993.  
 Draft Land Register consists of  
o Land Details 
 Land Parcel No & Extent in reference to the Sy. No. / Sub Div. No. 
as per Adangal 
 Land Nature & Classification as per Webland Adangal 
 Land Nature (Broad Category & Sub Category) & Classification 
(Broad Category & Sub Category) as per Resurvey 
 Nature of Land use & Source of Irrigation. 
 
o Pattadar Details 
 Khata No, Pattadar Name, Pattadar Relation Name 
 Enjoyer Name, Enjoyer Relation Name, Enjoyment Extent 
 Ownership details, Commination details, Unique ID 
 Status Land Title Confirmation. 
 Updation of Data through Draft Land Register Module

Page 65 of 144 
 o The data after completion of Ground Validation Activity shall be 
updated in Draft Land Register Online Module. 
o Utmost care shall be taken by the Tahsildar while updation of Draft 
Land Register, upon which the Online Form 38, Form-XIX will be 
generated. 
o The column – “Nature of Land Use ” shall be verified thoroughly, as 
the column decides to print the Title Deed cum Pattadar Pass Book 
for the Pattadar (Records selected under i) Agriculture, ii) 
Sericulture, iii) Horticulture; iv) Aquaculture; will be processed for 
generation of printing of Title Deed cum Pattadar Pass Books.  
(Records which were mentioned with “nature of land use” other than 
the three above – wont be processed for generation of Title Deed cum 
Pattadar Pass Book)  
o The column – “ Title Confirmation ” shall be verified thoroughly, as 
the column also decides to print the Title Deed cum Pattadar Pass 
Book for the Pattadars.  The selection of option “No” will move the 
respective record to “Dispute Layer”. 
 An option for confirmation of Title with “Yes” has been 
provided at i) Final ROR; ii) Dispute Layer, to enable the 
pattadars as “Title Confirmation – Yes”, whose title has been 
confirmed by the Competent Authority in post Ground 
Validation process. 
 Sharing of Data to Survey department  
o The data in Form 38 will be shared to Assistant Director, SSLR, of 
respective District will be verified and after Quality Check of the 
data, the Notification under section 13 of AP Survey & Boundary Act, 
1923.

o Resurvey Land Register was prepared in Form-XIX before notification of

in Form-IB for every separate Revenue Village.

[Note: The points mentioned hereunder pertaining to ROR are only part of IT Process and the entire process on field shall be followed as per 
A.P.Rights in Land and Pattadar Passbooks Act, 1971, A.P.Rights in Land and Pattadar Passbooks Rules, 1989 (as amended from 
time to time).  This SOP is a referral document and the actuals shall be observed following Acts, Rules.  The respective 
functionaries will he held responsible for the violations / deviations observed on the entire process ROR].  
 
RECORDING AUTHORITY:- 
 The District Collectors shall notify the Recording Authority as per Section 2(10) of 
A.P.Rights in Land and Pattadar Passbooks Act, 1971.  
 The Deputy Tahsildar (Re-Survey) of the respective Mandal shall be appointed as 
Recording Authority. 
 The Recording Authorities shall be appointed by designation and not by their 
name. 
 The proforma in which proceedings are to be issued by the Collector, appointing 
Recording Authority is enclosed in Forms / Formats. 
 Same Officer may be appointed as Recoding Authority for more than one Village. 
 Detailed procedure to be followed by the Recoding Authority for preparation and 
updations of ROR has been indicated from Rule 5 to Rule 14 of A.P.Rights in 
Land and Pattadar Passbooks Rules, 1989.  
SUBPHASE 2: PUBLICATION OF DRAFT ROR (FORM-III)  The Draft ROR will be automatically generated upon Final Approval of Draft Land 
Register by the Joint Collector.

Page 71 of 144 
  The Draft ROR so prepared shall be published by the Recording Authority by  
issue of a notification in Form-III as per Rule 10(1) of A.P.Rights in Land and 
Pattadar Passbooks Rules, 1989.  
SUBPHASE 3: OBJECTIONS ON DRAFT ROR, GRAMASABHA, ENQUIRY & 
DISPOSAL 
 Under Rule 10(1)(d), (As amended on 16th August, 2022), after publication of Draft 
ROR, shall publish a notice to read out Draft ROR not later than 15 days from the 
date of publication of Draft ROR (Form-III). 
 The Recording Authority shall also notify declaring his/her intention to hold an 
inquiry into claims & objections received on Draft ROR not later than 30 days from 
date of publication. 
 Any oral claims & objections received at Gramasabha shall be reduced to writing 
by the Recording Authority and the same shall be considered at the proposed 
enquiry. 
 The objections in Draft ROR shall be in Form-IIIA. 
 The Recording Authority shall enter all objections in the proforma as at register 
Form-IIIB. 
 Enquiries on Objections on Draft ROR shall be completed u/r 9 of A.P. 
Rights in Land and Pattadar Passbooks Rules, 1989  
 The Recording Authority has suomoto power to rectify Draft ROR u/r 12 of 
A.P.Rights in Land and Pattadar Passbooks Rules, 1989.  After all such 
enquiry he/she shall prepare final ROR.  
 The Collector / JC / DRO / RDO / any Deputy Collector nominated by 
Collector / Tahsildar shall have the power suomoto to scrutinize the Final 
ROR of the Village. u/r 13 of A.P.Rights in Land and Pattadar Passbooks 
Rules, 1989.  
 
I. Important aspects to be adhered to while disposing the claims 
 It must be ensured that the clear transfer of property is there to the claimant from 
the registered holder of the land. 
 The Recording Authority is simply making entries in ROR record as per the title 
already in possession by the claimant.

Page 72 of 144 
  The Recording Authority is not the Adjudication Authority. 
 The claimant must be in physical possession over the land. 
 If it is by succession, the joint statement by all the legal heirs shall be recorded.

SUBPHASE 4: PUBLICATION OF FINAL ROR REGISTER 
 The Recording Authority shall publish completion of ROR Process in Form-IV. 
 The publication shall be in State / District Gazette and in the manner as 
prescribed in Rule 5(2) of A.P.Rights in Land and Pattadar Passbooks Rules, 
1989. 
 The Final ROR prepared in Form-XIX (Resurvey Land Register) shall be read out 
by Recording Authority in a Grama Sabha within 7 days from the publication of 
Form-IV. 
 An online module has been provided to Recording Authority for updations and 
confirmation of Land Register to incorporate the changes received during the 
process of “Updation of Record of Rights”. 
 After publication of notification in Form-IV by the Recording Authority, the 
Tahsildar shall take necessary action to recast Form-XIX into Form I-B 
authenticating each entry.

 A. FAQS RELATED TO SUCCESSION CASES : 
S. No. Question Answer 
1 Whether in respect of “Fourthi” 
cases, registered documents are to be 
insisted upon for effecting transfer of 
registry? 
 “Fourthi” is a Persian word and corresponds 
to “Death” in English and (Maraninchuta) in 
Telugu. In “Fourthi” cases transfer of Registry 
is to be ordered in accordance with Rule 9 of 
Andhra Pradesh Record of Rights in Land

4 Property of mother given to her 
by her parents may be 
considered as a gift when it is 
partitioned between her sous 
and maybe exempted from 
Registration Fee There are two stages involved: — (1) Property 
transfer from parents to daughter and (2) 
Property transfer from daughter to her sons.   
 
In the 1st stage, if the transfer (gift) from 
parents to daughter was not registered, it needs 
to be vali-dated u/s. 5-A of ROR Act, if parents

Page 121 of 144 
 are alive. If the parents are dead, then patta 
may be transferred in the name of daughter as 
a case of succession, is in possession as per 
Revenue records.  
 
In the 2nd stage, since the concept of 
coparcenary right is not applicable to mother's 
property, if the mother is alive, there cannot be 
partition. Mother to sons should be validated 
u/s. 5-A of the Act, if the mother is alive. After 
the mother passes away, the sons become the 
heirs and they can partition the property 
among themselves. This partition does not 
require stamp duty or registration. Thus, after 
the mother's demise the sons can be registered 
as pattadars without stamp duty and 
registration fee.
